items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this afternoon and tomorrow morning. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Highest tide level is expected to be at Kilnsea Village, between 6:30 PM and 8:30 PM on 10/10/202,2 and 07:00 AM and 08:30 AM on 11/10/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated following the tide tomorrow morning, 11/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this evening. Highest tide level is expected to be at Kilnsea Village between 6:00 PM until 9:00 PM this evening. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated following the tide this evening, 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 16:00 on 10/10/22 and 4.75mAOD at 04:15 on 11/10/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 5 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 11/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.79mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.24m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.55mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.41m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.55mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.41m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 7pm and 9pm today, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.52mAODN at 8pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.5m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 11th October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7pm and 9pm today, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.52 mAODN at 8pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.5m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 11th October.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels are now receding following heavy rain yesterday evening with lake levels remaining high.  Levels will recede during today as no further rain is forecast.  Derwent Water remains high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water.  Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 11/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 00:45 AM on 11/10/2022.
Flooding is possible at the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale between 10:45 PM on 10/10/2022 and 02:45 AM on 11/10/2022.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The forecast for tomorrow’s high tide is below the Flood Alert threshold and therefore we are not expecting to issue any further Flood Alerts.  This message will be removed tomorrow morning 11/10/22 unless the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High water-levels and spray may overtop sea defences as a result of spring tides and strong winds. The forecast high water is 20:10 on 10/10/22 with a level of 6.28 mAOD and a Force 4 northerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail please refer to local tide tables.

Flooding to low-lying roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply for an hour either side of the high tide. We forecast that flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.
 
This message will be updated on Tuesday, 11/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.57mAOD at 15:00 on 10/10/22. 

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 5 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:15 on 10/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Alt, Formby to Huyton
items.message:
River levels have been falling steadily overnight as rainfall eases.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for today and tomorrow.
River levels are now returning to normal.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as conditions have improved. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood warning has now been removed, however a flood alert remains in force for the wider area. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message: River levels have risen again overnight due to recent heavy rain. Derwent Water remains high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.  Levels will start to recede during today as no further rain is forecast. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 11/10/2022 or as the situation changes.
